العمل من أجل التغيير | lang1 = | name_lang1 = | logo = | colorcode = | leader = [[Messaoud Ould Boulkheir]] | chairman = | chairperson = | president = | secretary_general = | spokesperson = | founder = | leader1_title = | leader1_name = | slogan = | founded = 1996 | dissolved = January 2002 | merger = | split = | predecessor = | merged = | successor = [[People's Progressive Alliance (Mauritania)|People's Progressive Alliance]] | headquarters = | newspaper = | paramilitary_wing = | student_wing = | youth_wing = | wing1_title = | wing1 = | membership_year = | membership = | ideology = | religion = | national = | international = | european = | europarl = | affiliation1_title = | affiliation1 = | colors = | symbol = | flag = | website = | state = Mauritania }} The '''Action for Change (AC)''' ({{lang-fr|Action pour le changement}}) was a [[political party]] in [[Mauritania]]. The party was led by Messaoud Ould Belkheir, and campaigned for greater rights for Mauritania's [[Haratin]] and black populations. The party was banned in January 2002. ==History== ===Electoral history=== The first election contested by the AC was the [[Mauritanian parliamentary election, 1996|1996 parliamentary election]], with the party coming third, with 5.3% of the vote and 1 seat in parliament. The party also went on to contest the [[Mauritanian parliamentary election, 2001|2001 parliamentary election]], winning 5.5% of the popular vote and 4 out of 81 seats. ===Dissolution=== The party was banned in January 2002 following accusations by the government that the party threatened Mauritanian national unity and was threatening Mauritania's relations with Senegal. Communications Minister Chyakh Ould Ely accused the party of being racist and violent. The party was allowed to keep its four parliamentary seats. Messaoud Ould Belkheir, the leader of the AC strongly denied the allegations made against the party, and claimed that the party was instead being banned as part of a crackdown in dissent by the government, and also because of the parties recent electoral gains.http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/1740098.stm ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Mauritanian political parties}} [[Category:Banned political parties]] [[Category:Black political parties]] [[Category:Defunct political parties in Mauritania]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1996]] [[Category:Political parties disestablished in 2002]] [[Category:2002 disestablishments in Africa]] {{Mauritania-party-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2015}} {{Use Indian English|date=December 2015}} [[File:AIKS demonstration2005.jpg|thumb|AIKS demonstrator in [[Delhi]]]]
'''All India Kisan Sabha''' ('''Akhil Bharatiya Kisan Sabha''') (AIKS), is the peasants front of [[Communist Party of India (Marxist)]], and works for farmers rights and anti-feudal movement in India,<ref>[http://www.hinduonnet.com/businessline/blnus/07141250.htm AP agri body seeks aid to tenant farmers] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090224191532/http://www.hinduonnet.com/businessline/blnus/07141250.htm |date=24 February 2009 }} ''[[The Hindu]]'', 14 November 2008.</ref> which traces its origin to [[All India Kisan Sabha]] founded in 1936.
It is sometimes referred to as All India Kisan Sabha (36 Canning Lane), to distinguish it from the AIKS of [[Communist Party of India]]. Both the Kisan federations are derived from the [[All India Kisan Sabha]] started by [[Swami Sahajanand Saraswati]] in 1936. The AIKS of CPI is sometimes called [[All India Kisan Sabha (Ajoy Bhavan)|AIKS (Ajoy Bhavan)]].
==History== [[File:Kerala2006 (19).JPG|thumb|Kerala Karshaka Sangam, the [[Kerala]] regional body of AIKS, mural in [[Allepey]]]] The Kisan Sabha movement started in [[Bihar]] under the leadership of [[Swami Sahajanand Saraswati]] who had formed in 1929 the [[Bihar Provincial Kisan Sabha]] (BPKS) in order to mobilise peasant grievances against the zamindari attacks on their occupancy rights.<ref>{{cite book | first = Śekhara | last = Bandyopādhyāya | title = From Plassey to Partition: A History of Modern India | publisher = [[Orient Longman]] | year = 2004 | isbn = 978-81-250-2596-2 | pages = 523 (at p 406) }}</ref>
Gradually the peasant movement intensified and spread across the rest of [[India]]. All these radical developments on the peasant front culminated in the formation of the [[All India Kisan Sabha]] (AIKS) at the [[Lucknow]] session of the [[Indian National Congress]] in April 1936 with [[Swami Sahajanand Saraswati]] elected as its first President.<ref>{{cite book | first = Śekhara | last = Bandyopādhyāya | title = From Plassey to Partition: A History of Modern India | publisher = [[Orient Longman]] | year = 2004 | isbn = 978-81-250-2596-2 | pages = 523 (at p 407) }}</ref> The other prominent members of this Sabha were [[N.G. Ranga]], [[Ram Manohar Lohia]], [[Jayaprakash Narayan]], [[Acharya Narendra Dev]] and Bankim Mukerji.
The main aim of the sabha were:- 1)To save the peasants from exploitation by any section of the society. 2)Abolition of [[zamindari]] and [[jagirdari]] system 3)To save the peasants from economic exploitation 4)Ownership of land by the peasants 5)Reduction in the rates of land revenue 6)Waiving of debts 7)Better arrangements of irrigation 8)To give recognition to Kisan Sabhas
The Kisan Sabha started agitations against the landlords. In the 1937-38, they started a movement for the ownership of the lands by the peasants who worked on it and to bring about the end of forced labour. The farmers revolted against the Jagirdars who did not give them any rights on the land.As a result, the conflict between the peasants and the landlords became more intense. The government arrested 600 Kisan demonstrators and suppressed the movement.
In 1939, when the second world war began, the Government enforced the Defence of India Rules strictly to crush the peasant movement. But the Kisan union continued struggle forcefully.
==Organisation== The address of AIKS is 36, Canning Lane, [[New Delhi]]. *[[File:Amra-ram.jpg|thumb|[[Amara Ram (CPI-M Politician)|Amra Ram]], Incumbent President of AIKS]]National President: Ashok Dhawale * National Vice-president: [[Amara Ram (CPI-M politician)|Amra Ram]], S Ramachandran Pillai, K Varadharajan, Madan Ghosh, K Balakrishnan, S Malla Reddy and SK Preeja (woman) * National general secretary: [[Hannan Mollah]] * National joint secretary: [[Vijoo Krishnan]], NK Shukla, EP Jayarajan, Nripen Choudhary, KK Raghesh, Jitendra Choudhary, Amal Haldar and Badal Saroj <ref>[https://peoplesdemocracy.in/2017/1015_pd/aiks-34th-conference-hisar-organise-unite-launch-issue-based-struggles-overcome] ''[[People's Democracy (newspaper)|People's Democracy]]'', 15 October 2017.</ref>

{{Redirect|American empire||American Empire (disambiguation){{!}}American Empire}} [[File:US military bases in the world 2007.svg|thumb|450px|U.S. military presence around the world in 2007. {{as of|2013}}, the U.S. still had many [[List of United States military bases|bases and troops stationed globally]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acq.osd.mil/ie/download/bsr/Base%20Structure%20Report%202013_Baseline%2030%20Sept%202012%20Submission.pdf|title=Base Structure Report : FY 2013 Baseline|publisher=United States Department of Defense|access-date=2017-04-09|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150221030636/http://www.acq.osd.mil/ie/download/bsr/Base%20Structure%20Report%202013_Baseline%2030%20Sept%202012%20Submission.pdf|archive-date=2015-02-21|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Their presence has generated controversy and opposition by some in foreign countries.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.vice.com/article/protesters-accuse-us-of-imperialism-as-obama-rekindles-military-deal-with-philippines|title=Protesters Accuse US of 'Imperialism' as Obama Rekindles Military Deal With Philippines|work=VICE News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.popularresistance.org/anti-us-base-candidate-wins-okinawa-governor-race/|title=Anti-US Base Candidate Wins Okinawa Governor Race|work=PopularResistance.Org}}</ref> {{legend|#0000ff|More than 1,000 U.S. troops}} {{legend|#9ccbe1|100–1,000 U.S. troops}} {{legend|#f7931d|Use of military facilities}}]] [[File:Location NATO 2017 blue.svg|upright=1.5|thumb|right|Member states of NATO]] {{American Empire}}
'''American imperialism''' is a policy aimed at extending the political, economic, and cultural control of the United States government over areas beyond its boundaries. It can be accomplished in any number of ways: by military conquest, by [[treaty]], by [[subsidization]], by economic penetration through private companies followed by [[Interventionism (politics)|intervention]] when those interests are threatened, or by [[regime change]].<ref>[http://ic.galegroup.com/ic/uhic/ReferenceDetailsPage/ReferenceDetailsWindow?failOverType=&query=&prodId=UHIC&windowstate=normal&contentModules=&display-query=&mode=view&displayGroupName=Reference&dviSelectedPage=&limiter=&currPage=&disableHighlighting=false&displayGroups=&sortBy=&zid=&search_within_results=&p=UHIC&action=e&catId=&activityType=&scanId=&documentId=GALE%7CCX3611000416&source=Bookmark&u=wale31173&jsid=998307cb26570bbb35c57f6ee059cff9 "History in Context: Imperialism" ''Gale Encyclopedia of U.S. Economic History'', 2015]</ref>
The concept of expanding territorial control was popularized in the 19th century as the doctrine of [[Manifest Destiny]] and was realized through conquests such as the [[Mexican–American War]] of 1846, which resulted in the [[Mexican Cession|annexation of 525,000 square miles of Mexican territory]].<ref name="lens">{{cite book |last1=Lens|first1=Sidney|authorlink1=Sidney Lens|last2=Zinn|first2=Howard |title=The Forging of the American Empire|publisher=Pluto Press|location=London|year=2003|origyear=1971 |isbn=0-7453-2100-3 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qvLfIHqkOOAC}}</ref><ref name="Field 644–668">{{cite journal |title=American Imperialism: The Worst Chapter i Almost Any Book |last=Field |first=James A., Jr. |journal=The American Historical Review |volume=83 |issue=3 |date=June 1978 |pages=644–668 |doi=10.2307/1861842 |jstor=1861842}}</ref> While the US government does not refer to itself as an empire, the continuing phenomenon has been acknowledged by mainstream [[Western culture|Western]] writers including [[Max Boot]], [[Arthur Schlesinger, Jr.|Arthur Schlesinger]], and [[Niall Ferguson]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.brookings.edu/opinions/american-empire-not-if-but-what-kind/|title=American Empire, Not ‘If’ but ‘What Kind’|first=Ivo H. Daalder and James M.|last=Lindsay|publisher=}}</ref>
== Imperialism ==
=== Indian Wars and Manifest Destiny === {{Further|Empire of Liberty|Manifest Destiny|Modern empires|Overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii}} [[File:School Begins (Puck Magazine 1-25-1899).jpg|upright=1.2|thumb|Caricature showing [[Uncle Sam]] lecturing four children labelled [[Philippines]], [[Hawaii]], [[Puerto Rico]] and [[Cuba]], in front of children holding books labelled with various [[U.S. state]]s. A black boy is washing windows, a [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] sits separate from the class, and a Chinese boy is outside the door. The caption reads: "School Begins. Uncle Sam (to his new class in Civilization): Now, children, you've got to learn these lessons whether you want to or not! But just take a look at the class ahead of you, and remember that, in a little while, you will feel as glad to be here as they are!"]]
[[Thomas Jefferson]], in the 1790s, awaited the fall of the [[Spanish Empire]] "until our population can be sufficiently advanced to gain it from them piece by piece".<ref>{{cite book|author1=Susan Welch|author2=John Gruhl|author3=Susan M. Rigdon|author4=Sue Thomas|title=Understanding American Government|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GT-8oHlIp1UC|year=2011|publisher=Cengage Learning|isbn=978-0-495-91050-3|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=GT–8oHlIp1UC&pg=PA583 583], [https://books.google.com/books?id=GT–8oHlIp1UC&pg=PA671 671] (note 3)}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Walter LaFeber|title=Inevitable Revolutions: The United States in Central America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RqMp5TsWCqkC|year=1993|publisher=W. W. Norton & Company|isbn=978-0-393-30964-5|page=19}}</ref> In turn, historian [[Sidney Lens]] notes that "the urge for expansion{{spaced ndash}}at the expense of other peoples{{spaced ndash}}goes back to the beginnings of the United States itself".<ref name="lens" /> Yale historian [[Paul Kennedy (historian)|Paul Kennedy]] put it, "From the time the first settlers arrived in [[Virginia]] from [[England]] and started moving westward, this was an imperial nation, a conquering nation."<ref name="Trends 2002">Emily Eakin "Ideas and Trends: All Roads Lead To DC" New York Times, March 31, 2002.</ref> Detailing George Washington's description of the early United States as an "infant empire",<ref>[http://press.princeton.edu/chapters/i9118.pdf Contending with the American Empire : Introduction].</ref> Benjamin Franklin's writing that "the Prince that acquires new Territory ... removes the Natives to give his own People Room ... may be properly called [Father] of [his] Nation",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.columbia.edu/~lmg21/ash3002y/earlyac99/documents/observations.html|title=Franklin's "Observations Concerning the Increase of Mankind... "|website=www.columbia.edu}}</ref> and Thomas Jefferson's statement that the United States "must be viewed as the nest from which all America, North & South is to be peopled",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jeffersonswest.unl.edu/archive/view_doc.php?id=jef.00071|title=Envisaging the West: Thomas Jefferson and the Roots of Lewis and Clark|website=jeffersonswest.unl.edu}}</ref> Noam Chomsky said that "the United States is the one country that exists, as far as I know, and ever has, that was founded as an empire explicitly".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://chomsky.info/20080424/|title=Modern-Day American Imperialism: Middle East and Beyond|website=chomsky.info}}</ref><ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7PdJ9TAdTdA</ref>
A national drive for territorial acquisition across the continent was popularized in the 19th century as the ideology of [[Manifest Destiny]]. It came to be realized with the [[Mexican–American War]] of 1846, which resulted in the [[Mexican Cession|annexation of 525,000 square miles of Mexican territory]], stretching up to the Pacific coast.<ref name="lens"/><ref name="Field 644–668"/>
President James Monroe presented his famous [[Monroe Doctrine|doctrine for the western hemisphere]] in 1823. Historians have observed that while the Monroe Doctrine contained a commitment to resist colonialism from Europe, it had some aggressive implications for American policy, since there were no limitations on the US's own actions mentioned within it. Scholar Jay Sexton notes that the tactics used to implement the doctrine were "modeled after those employed by [[British Empire|British imperialists]]" in their territorial competition with Spain and France.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tmp4DQAAQBAJ&pg=PT35&dq=outside+in.+lord+canning&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjtu7irlYXZAhVvluAKHTawBMYQ6AEILzAC#v=onepage&q=Modeled%20after%20British%20imperialists&f=false|title=Outside In: The Transnational Circuitry of US History|last=Preston|first=Andrew|last2=Rossinow|first2=Doug|date=2016-11-15|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780190459871|language=en}}</ref> Eminent historian [[William Appleman Williams]] dryly described it as "imperial anti-colonialism." <ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u4GVKXN8SWYC&printsec=frontcover&dq=imperial+anti-colonialism&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjwh9D97fbYAhUFTd8KHTcuC2MQ6AEIKjAB#v=onepage&q=imperial%20anti-colonialism&f=false|title=The Monroe Doctrine: Empire and Nation in Nineteenth-Century America|last=Sexton|first=Jay|date=2011-03-15|publisher=Farrar, Straus and Giroux|year=|isbn=9781429929288|location=|pages=2–9|language=en}}</ref>
The [[American Indian Wars|Indian Wars]] against the indigenous population began in the British era. Their escalation under the federal republic allowed the US to dominate North America and carve out the 48 [[Contiguous United States|continental states]]. This is now understood to be an explicitly colonial process, as the Native American nations were usually recognized as sovereign entities prior to annexation. Their sovereignty was systematically undermined by US state policy (usually involving unequal or [[List of United States treaties|broken treaties]]) and [[Settler colonialism|white settler-colonialism.]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Williams|first=Walter L.|date=1980|title=United States Indian Policy and the Debate over Philippine Annexation: Implications for the Origins of American Imperialism|jstor=1887638|journal=The Journal of American History|volume=66|issue=4|pages=810–831|doi=10.2307/1887638}}</ref> The climax of this process was the [[California Genocide|California genocide]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://yalebooks.yale.edu/book/9780300181364/american-genocide|title=American Genocide {{!}} Yale University Press|website=yalebooks.yale.edu|access-date=2018-01-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.newsweek.com/2016/08/26/california-native-americans-genocide-490824.html|title=California's state-sanctioned genocide of Native Americans|date=2016-08-17|work=Newsweek|access-date=2018-01-26|language=en}}</ref>
=== New Imperialism and "The White Man's Burden"=== {{Further|History of the Philippines (1898–1946)|Philippine–American War|Big Stick ideology|Roosevelt corollary}} [[File:Victor Gillam A Thing Well Begun Is Half Done 1899 Cornell CUL PJM 1136 01.jpg|upright=1|thumb|This cartoon reflects the view of [[Judge (magazine)|Judge magazine]] regarding America's imperial ambitions following a quick victory in the Spanish–American War of 1898.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://digital.library.cornell.edu/catalog/ss:3293822|title=A Thing Well Begun Is Half Done|work=Persuasive Maps: PJ Mode Collection|publisher=Cornell University}}</ref> The American flag flies from the Philippines and Hawaii in the Pacific to Cuba and Puerto Rico in the Caribbean.]] A variety of factors converged during the "[[New Imperialism]]" of the late 19th century, when the United States and the other [[great powers]] rapidly expanded their overseas territorial possessions. Some of these are explained, or used as examples for the various forms of New Imperialism. * The prevalence of overt racism, notably [[John Fiske (philosopher)|John Fiske]]'s conception of [[British people|Anglo-Saxon]] racial superiority, and [[Josiah Strong]]'s call to "civilize and Christianize"—all manifestations of a growing [[Social Darwinism]] and racism in some schools of American political thought.<ref>Thomas Friedman, "The Lexus and the Olive Tree", p. 381, and Manfred Steger, "Globalism: The New Market Ideology," and Jeff Faux, "Flat Note from the Pied Piper of Globalization," Dissent, Fall 2005, pp. 64–67.</ref> * Early in his career, as Assistant Secretary of the Navy, [[Theodore Roosevelt]] was instrumental in preparing the Navy for the [[Spanish–American War]]<ref>[[H. W. Brands|Brands, Henry William]]. (1997). ''T.R.: The Last Romantic.'' New York: Basic Books. Reprinted 2001, full biography [http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/36954615?referer=di&ht=edition OCLC 36954615], ch 12</ref> and was an enthusiastic proponent of testing the U.S. military in battle, at one point stating "I should welcome almost any war, for I think this country needs one".<ref name="PBS1">{{cite web |first= |url=https://www.pbs.org/crucible/tl7.html |title=April 16, 1897: T. Roosevelt Appointed Assistant Secretary of the Navy |work=Crucible of Empire—Timeline|publisher=[[PBS Online]]|accessdate=July 26, 2007}}</ref><ref name="PBS2">{{cite web |first= |url=https://www.pbs.org/crucible/Transcript.txt |title=Transcript For "Crucible Of Empire" |work=Crucible of Empire—Timeline|publisher=PBS Online|accessdate=July 26, 2007}}</ref><ref>Tilchin, William N. Theodore Roosevelt and the [[British Empire]]: A Study in Presidential Statecraft (1997)</ref>
Roosevelt claimed that he rejected imperialism, but he embraced the near-identical doctrine of [[expansionism]]. When Rudyard Kipling wrote the imperialist poem "[[The White Man's Burden]]" for Roosevelt, the politician told colleagues that it was “rather poor poetry, but good sense from the expansion point of view." <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://historymatters.gmu.edu/d/5478/|title="The White Man's Burden": Kipling's Hymn to U.S. Imperialism|website=historymatters.gmu.edu|access-date=2018-01-25}}</ref> Roosevelt was so committed to dominating Spain's former colonies that he proclaimed his own [[Roosevelt Corollary|corollary to the Monroe Doctrine]] as justification,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.americanforeignrelations.com/E-N/Imperialism-The-roosevelt-corollary.html|title=The roosevelt corollary - Imperialism|website=www.americanforeignrelations.com|language=en|access-date=2018-01-27}}</ref> although his ambitions extended even further, into the Far East. Scholars have documented the resemblance and collaboration between US and British military activities in the Pacific at this time.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K_Lx0KCui5IC&pg=PA509&dq=walter+l.+philippine&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiR9Nn21fPYAhVjZN8KHU82DwAQ6AEIQDAF#v=snippet&q=Genocidal&f=false|title=The Blood of Government: Race, Empire, the United States, and the Philippines|last=Kramer|first=Paul A.|date=2006-12-13|publisher=Univ of North Carolina Press|isbn=9780807877173|language=en}}</ref>
Industry and trade are two of the most prevalent motivations of imperialism. [[Banana Wars|American intervention in both Latin America and Hawaii]] resulted in multiple industrial investments, including the popular industry of [[Dole Food Company|Dole]] bananas. If the United States was able to annex a territory, in turn they were granted access to the trade and capital of those territories. In 1898, Senator [[Albert Beveridge]] proclaimed that an expansion of markets was absolutely necessary, "American factories are making more than the American people can use; American soil is producing more than they can consume. Fate has written our policy for us; the trade of the world must and shall be ours."<ref>Zinn, Howard. ''A People's History of the United States: 1492–2001''. New York: HarperCollins, 2003. Print.</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jVooDgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=theodore+roosevelt+imperialism+primary+sources&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi-6PjLluzYAhVP7mMKHWODDw8Q6AEIRDAG#v=snippet&q=beveridge.%20Roosevelt&f=false|title=Honor in the Dust: Theodore Roosevelt, War in the Philippines, and the Rise and Fall of America's Imperial Dream|last=Jones|first=Gregg|date=2013|publisher=Penguin|year=|isbn=9780451239181|location=|pages=169–170|language=en}}</ref>
American rule of ceded Spanish territory was not uncontested. The [[Philippine Revolution]] had begun in August 1896 against Spain, and after the defeat of Spain in the [[Battle of Manila Bay]], began again in earnest, culminating in the [[Philippine Declaration of Independence]] and the establishment of the [[First Philippine Republic]]. The [[Philippine–American War]] ensued, with extensive damage and death, ultimately resulting in the defeat of the Philippine Republic.{{sfn|Schirmer|Shalom|1987|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=TXE73VWcsEEC&pg=PA18 18], [https://books.google.com/books?id=TXE73VWcsEEC&pg=PA40-41 40–41]}}<ref>[[s:Secretary Root's Record:"Marked Severities" in Philippine Warfare|Secretary Root's Record: "Marked Severities" in Philippine Warfare]], Wikisource (multiple mentions)</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Zinn|first=Howard|title= A PEOPLE's HISTORY of the UNITED STATES 1492—PRESENT|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V_h2BAAAQBAJ|year=2014|publisher=Time Apt. Group|isbn=978-615-5505-13-3|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=V_h2BAAAQBAJ&pg=PT204 unnumbered]}}</ref> According to scholars such as [[Gavan McCormack]] and [[E. San Juan]], the American [[counterinsurgency]] resulted in [[genocide]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/26239244/U.S._GENOCIDE_IN_THE_PHILIPPINES_AND_THE_CONTINUING_STRUGGLE_FOR_NATIONAL-DEMOCRATIC_LIBERATION||title=U.S. Genocide in the Philippines: A Case of Guilt, Shame, or Amnesia?|author=E. San Juan, Jr.|date=March 22, 2005|authorlink=E. San Juan, Jr.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wlqHDAAAQBAJ&pg=PR12&lpg=PR12&dq=mccormack.+e.+san+juan.+genocide&source=bl&ots=Nj6Yag8jQ4&sig=wOSGPb7wT5Qh3w4VT0FMZit3Miw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiIw5_l-_DYAhVJON8KHbtUAqoQ6AEwAXoECAsQAQ#v=onepage&q=mccormack.%20e.%20san%20juan.%20genocide&f=false|title=U.S. Imperialism and Revolution in the Philippines|last=Jr|first=E. San Juan|date=2007-09-03|publisher=Springer|year=|isbn=9780230607033|location=|pages=Xii-xviii|language=en}}</ref>
[[File:GreaterAmericaMap.jpg|thumb|A map of "Greater America" c. 1900, including overseas territories.]] The maximum geographical extension of American direct political and military control happened in the [[aftermath of World War II]], in the period after the surrender and occupations of [[Allied-occupied Germany|Germany]] and [[Allied-occupied Austria|Austria]] in May and later [[Occupation of Japan|Japan]] and [[United States Army Military Government in Korea|Korea]] in [[Japanese Instrument of Surrender|September 1945]] and before the independence of the [[Philippines]] in [[Treaty of Manila (1946)|July 1946]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.ph/republic-day/|title=Philippine Republic Day|work=www.gov.ph}}</ref>
[[Benevolent Assimilation (book)|Stuart Creighton Miller]] says that the public's sense of innocence about [[Realpolitik]] impairs popular recognition of U.S. imperial conduct.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Zj6g2ag47TwC&pg=PA52&lpg=PA52&dq=to+exercise+future+domination.+mckinley&source=bl&ots=x4t6gJ86pw&sig=KGSuiCiRpwqIpyUgUVrZiE7bllc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwj9xcaUv-7YAhVC2FMKHQIrDMEQ6AEwA3oECAsQAQ#v=onepage&q=to%20exercise%20future%20domination.%20mckinley&f=false|title=Benevolent Assimilation: The American Conquest of the Philippines, 1899-1903|last=Miller|first=Stuart Creighton|date=1982|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=030016193X|language=en}}</ref> The resistance to actively occupying foreign territory has led to policies of exerting influence via other means, including governing other countries via surrogates or [[puppet regime]]s, where domestically unpopular governments survive only through U.S. support.<ref>Johnson, Chalmers, ''Blowback: The Costs and Consequences of American Empire'' (2000), pp. 72–79</ref>
The Philippines is sometimes cited as an example. After Philippine independence, the US continued to direct the country through Central Intelligence Agency operatives like [[Edward Lansdale]]. As [[Raymond Bonner]] and other historians note, Lansdale controlled the career of President [[Ramon Magsaysay]], going so far as to physically beat him when the Philippine leader attempted to reject a speech the CIA had written for him. American agents also drugged sitting President [[Elpidio Quirino]] and prepared to assassinate Senator [[Claro M. Recto|Claro Recto]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/19/world/new-book-on-marcos-says-us-knew-of-his-72-martial-law-plans.html|title=New Book on Marcos Says U.S. Knew of His '72 Martial-Law Plans|last=Butterfield|first=Fox|date=1987-04-19|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-01-24|last2=Times|first2=Special to the New York|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ntEJR0FuNmoC&pg=PA33&lpg=PA33&dq=magsaysay.+lansdale.+speech&source=bl&ots=5rDGb7J1lc&sig=QGgwydszKtZrD_VzYW7tzHjnLOU&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjRvfiR4u_YAhVMrFMKHTWVDTQQ6AEwAXoECBIQAQ#v=onepage&q=magsaysay.%20lansdale.%20speech&f=false|title=Edward Lansdale's Cold War|last=Nashel|first=Jonathan|date=2005|publisher=Univ of Massachusetts Press|year=|isbn=1558494642|location=|pages=32|language=en}}</ref> Prominent Filipino historian Roland G. Simbulan has called the CIA "US imperialism's [[CIA activities in the Philippines|clandestine apparatus in the Philippines]]".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.derechos.org/nizkor/filipinas/doc/cia.html|title=Equipo Nizkor – Covert Operations and the CIA's Hidden History in the Philippines|last=Simbulan|first=Roland G.|date=August 18, 2000|website=www.derechos.org|access-date=2018-01-23}} Lecture at the University of the Philippines-Manila, Rizal Hall, Padre Faura, Manila</ref>
The U.S. retained dozens of military bases, including a few major ones. In addition, Philippine independence was qualified by legislation passed by the [[U.S. Congress]]. For example, the [[Bell Trade Act]] provided a mechanism whereby U.S. import quotas might be established on Philippine articles which "are coming, or are likely to come, into substantial competition with like articles the product of the United States". It further required U.S. citizens and corporations be granted equal access to Philippine minerals, forests, and other natural resources.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chanrobles.com/commonwealthactno733.htm#.Uf5I7dI_vz4|title=Commonwealth Act No. 733|date=April 30, 1946|publisher=Chan Robles Law Library}}</ref> In hearings before the Senate Committee on Finance, Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs [[William L. Clayton]] described the law as "clearly inconsistent with the basic foreign economic policy of this country" and "clearly inconsistent with our promise to grant the Philippines genuine independence".<ref>{{cite book|last=Jenkins|first=Shirley|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=x4qaAAAAIAAJ|title=American Economic Policy Toward the Philippines|publisher=Stanford University Press|isbn=0-8047-1139-9|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=x4qaAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA62&lpg=PA62 62]|year=1954}}</ref>
