{{Orphan|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox organization | name = | logo = | type = | founded_date = 2002.05.23. | tax_id = | registration_id = | founder = Disabled military veterans and amputees | location = Sime Miljusa 2,
[[Banja Luka]], 78 000
[[Republika Srpska]],
Bosnia and Herzegovina | origins = | key_people = | area_served = {{flagicon|Bosnia and Herzegovina}} [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] | product = | mission = | focus = support programs for amputees and other people with disabilities | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | subsid = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = | homepage = http://www.udas.rs.ba/ | dissolved = | footnotes = }} '''The Organization of Amputees Republike Srpske''' ('''UDAS''') (Serbian: Организација Aмпутираца УДАС Републике Српске/ Organizacija amputiraca ”UDAS” Republike Srpske) is registered as a [[nonprofit organization]] and [[non-governmental organization]] based in [[Banja Luka|Banja Luka, Bosnia and Herzegovina]], founded by [[Amputation|amputees]] which are mostly landmine victims in order to provides support for victims of landmines, [[Unexploded ordnance|unexploded ordnance (UXO)]], [[cluster munition]] and other persons with [[Disability|disabilities]] and their families to integrate them back into the community, thus enabling them to live normal lives. == Overview == Organization of Amputees UDAS Republike Srpske is intended to protect and promote [[Disability rights movement|rights of disabled population]] regardless of type and manner of acquiring disability. The UDAS provides assistance primarily to survivors and their families, as well as other people with disabilities with various types of projects and activities: [[peer support]], referrals, social and economic [[Inclusion (disability rights)|inclusion]] activities, legal advising, survivors and disability rights campaign, [[Disability in the arts|disability arts]] and [[disabled sports]].{{cite web|title=Casualties and Victim Assistance|url=http://archives.the-monitor.org/index.php/cp/display/region_profiles/theme/2466|publisher=Landmine and cluster muniction rapport|accessdate= 1 September 2013}} {{cite web|title=Newsletter.No3|url=http://www.rcc.int/download/docs/Final_Newsletter+No3_RHDCMNH.pdf/eb94245439d21316c9faddb9b4db3c07|publisher=Regional Corporaction Council|accessdate=2 December 2013}} The UDAS maintains partnership with numbers of local and regional organizations that are supporting people with disabilities and, or organizations which are working on landmine cleansing. In addition to that, UDAS has partnerships with the city of Banja Luka and Ministries on both levels: Republic of Srpska and Bosnia and Herzegovina. UDAS participated and,or created various numbers of projects and activities supported by local, republican and state government, as well as [[United States Agency for International Development|USAID]], EU and Norwegian Embassy in Sarajevo.{{cite web|title=EU-supported projects|url=http://europa.ba/?p=38663|publisher=Delegation of European Union to Bosnia and Herzegovina|accessdate=1 December 2015}}{{cite web|title=The International day for Mine Awareness and Assistance in Mine Action|url=http://www.norveska.ba/News_and_events/Society-and-Policy/The-Norwegian-Embassy-supports-The-International-day-for-Mine-Awareness-and-Assistance-in-Mine-Action-/#.VzWMD9J97cf|publisher=The Norwegian Embassy in Sarajevo|accessdate=4 April 2016}} The organization covers the entire area of the Republic of Srpska through five regional associations in Banja Luka, Doboj, Bijeljina, Istocno Sarajevo and Trebinje. It has around 4500 members, mostly victims of the mines and cluster munitions in BiH. The leaders of the UDAS are the survivors themselves. UDAS is a member of KOMA coaliction(Coalition for marginalized groups) and [[International Campaign to Ban Landmines|ICBL]]-[[Cluster Munition Coalition|CMC]] coaliction.{{cite web|title=members|url=http://www.stopclustermunitions.org/en-gb/about-us/who-we-are/members/icbl-cmc-members.aspx|publisher=Cluster Munition Coalition|accessdate= 1 September 2013}}{{cite web|title=KOMA members|url=http://koma.ba/clanice-koalicije-koma/|publisher=KOMA|accessdate=1 September 2015}} === Mission and values === :Guided by philanthropy, values of UDAS are premised on the belief that those with disabilities are entitled to lives of opportunity, independence and dignity. Moreover, society as a whole benefits when population with disability is included and empowered. UDAS mission is to promotes and protects the human rights of people with disabilities and actively supports their full inclusion and participation in the community throughout their lifetimes. UDAS vision is to create a prosperous society, society without barriers and prejudices ([[ableism]]) in which everybody has equal rights and equal opportunities. === Brief history === :In the aftermath of Yugoslav wars, disabled population in Bosnia and Herzegovina found themselves seriously disadvantaged. People with disabilities with serious lack of governmental support, faced poverty and social exclusion, unequal access to health services, prejudices and discrimination.{{cite web|title=Osobe sa invaliditetom u BiH:Diskriminacija u zakonodavstvu i praksi|url=http://www.slobodnaevropa.org/a/25438831.html|publisher=Radio Slobodna Evropa|accessdate=28 Jun 2014}} In order to meet the basic needs of amputees (civilian and military) and other people with disability, UDAS is founded in 2002. by mostly landmine victims. In the beginning, UDAS had a lot of educational support from former local non-governmental organization ‘Landmine Survivors Initiatives’ (LSI). The organization began as 'The Association of Amputees UDAS Srpske' but later became 'The Organization of Amputees UDAS of Republic of Srpska'. In 2006 due to gained achievements and support given to persons with disabilities Government of Republic of Srpska declared Udas as an organisation of public interest. == Land mine situation == During the 1992–95 [[Bosnian War|Bosnian war]], an estimated two million landmines were planted. Majority of locations of the landmines were not thoroughly mapped out and documented. This lack of documentation has complicated the demining process. Beside that, Bosnia’s mountainous and densely forested territory pose a major impediment to the demining process, as the best mechanical methods for demining only work on flat land. Thus, the demining process has largely been done by hand, an assuredly slow and laborious undertaking{{cite web|title=Shifting minefields bosnias violent legacy in the wake of the balkan floods|url=http://www.ssrresourcecentre.org/2014/05/28/shifting-minefields-bosnias-violent-legacy-in-the-wake-of-the-balkan-floods/|publisher=The SSR Resource Centre| accessdate=28 May 2014}} As a result of it Bosnia and Herzegovina is still one of the most mine contaminated countries in South Easter Europe region. Current size of mine suspected area in BiH covers 1,165 km2 or 2.3% of the total country size, with 1,417 affected communities, directly impacting the safety of about 538,500 people, or about 15% of the total country population.{{cite web|title=PRESS RELEASE|url=http://www.bhmac.org/en/stream.daenet?sta=3&pid=880&kat=19|publisher=bhmac|accessdate=29 September 2015}} Cluster munition suspect area is 8.76 km2. An estimated 120,000 mines remain, according to the Bosnia and Herzegovina Mine Action Centre(BHMAC). For the period 1992–2013, BHMAC recorded a total of 8,319 mine/[[Unexploded ordnance|UXO]] casualties: 1,833 killed, 6,039 survivors, and 447 unknown. In many cases, one or more limbs had to be amputated. Than number keeps growing every year.{{cite web|title=Bosnia and Herzegovina: Casualties and Victim Assistance|url=http://www.the-monitor.org/en-gb/reports/2016/bosnia-and-herzegovina/casualties-and-victim-assistance.aspx|publisher=Mine Monitor|accessdate=13 August 2015}} Ten people were involved in land mine accidents in January 2014 alone, including a ten-year-old boy who died in an explosion.{{cite web|title=Bosnia mines still kill 20 years later|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2014/02/bosnia-mines-still-kill-20-years-later-201425131626160304.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=12 February 2014}} In May 2014, BiH was severely affected by the worst [[2014 Southeast Europe floods|Balkan flood]] in over a century. Almost one third of Bosnia is affected by floods with houses, roads and railway lines being submerged in the north eastern part of the country.{{cite web|title=The Balkans: Worst floods in Century continue to cause havoc|url=http://www.ifrc.org/en/news-and-media/news-stories/international/the-balkans-worst-floods-in-century-continue-to-cause-havoc-65957/|publisher=IFRC|accessdate=18 May 2014}} One million people – approximately a quarter of the population – have been affected by the floods. Around of 70 percent of the flood-affected zones were in areas contaminated by mines.{{cite web|title=Bosnia and Herzegovina floods, 2014.|url=http://europa.ba/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/delegacijaEU_2014090308560389eng.pdf|publisher=Delegation of European Union to Bosnia and Herzegovina|accessdate=5 Jun 2014}} Bosnian authorities reported that the floods had moved mines, cluster munitions, and unexploded ordnance (UXO), and had damaged minefield fencing and signs. At an ammunition depot in [[Orašje, Bosnia|Orašje]], some 250 tons of ammunition were reported as being under water on 25 May 2014. Landmine Survivors Initiatives reported that more than 3,000 mine survivors were living in the flood-affected region.{{cite web|title=Mine Action|url=http://archives.the-monitor.org/index.php/cp/display/region_profiles/theme/3296#_ftn6|publisher=Landmine and cluster muniction rapport|accessdate= 9 October 2014}} == Inclusion == The UDAS is constantly working to improve the quality of life of persons with disabilities. UDAS actively organizes and participate in a range of innovative projects and activities together with organizations that focus on inclusion of people with disabilities. These activities projects cover community life, healthcare, employment, legislation, art and healthy lifestyle. === Health and social welfare === In cooperation with Institute for physical medicine and rehabilitation “Dr Miroslav Zotović”, UDAS provides an individual and group peer to support people with disabilities, organizes educational seminars on topic of healthcare and social welfare, psychological counseling for disabled war veterans, amputees and mine victims.{{cite web|title=Socijalni radnik u timu za lječenje i rehabilitaciju angiološki bolesnika i osoba sa amputacijama|url=http://www.zotovicbl.com/2015/04/socijalni-radnik-u-timu-za-lijecenje-i-rehabilitaciju-angioloskih-bolesnika-i-osoba-sa-amputacijama/|publisher=Zavod za fizikalnu medicinu i rehabilitaciju Dr Miroslav Zotovic|accessdate=1 Jun 2015}}{{cite web|title=Peer Support and Trauma Recovery|url=http://www.jmu.edu/cisr/journal/15.1/feature/macauley/macauley.shtml|publisher=Center for International Stabilization and Recovery,by Cameron Macauley|accessdate=}}{{cite web|title=Mirror Therapy Introduced To Bosnia|url=http://endthepainprojectupdate.blogspot.ba/2013/10/mirror-therapy-introduced-to-bosnia.html|publisher=End The Pain Project|accessdate=15 October 2013}} All activities are led by professional associates, doctors and specialists. Also, in co-operation with Family Medicine Service, UDAS offers referrals for [[Community-based rehabilitation|CBR centers]]. === Financial inclusion === Landmine contamination in B&H has a significant impact on its economy. In particular branch of tourism, hunting and fishing, agriculture, animal husbandry as well as a safe use of natural resources. As a result of post-war unprosperous economy, persons with disabilities on average as a group experience worse socioeconomic situation, having to face at the same time with [[Disability and poverty|unemployment]] and [[Ableism|prejudges]] especially about their employment. People with disabilities in BiH live below the poverty threshold. As a result of it persons with disabilities are usually been perceived as charity case.{{cite web|title=Invalide niko ne zapošljava|url=http://www.nezavisne.com/novosti/bih/Invalide-niko-ne-zaposljava/17537|publisher=Nezavisne novine|accessdate=2 December 2007}} In order to fight poverty, main economic strategy of UDAS is to increase the income of persons with disabilities, through improvement of employment and self-employment opportunities. To do so, UDAS in co-operation with relevant foundations and/or institutions provides support in [[informal employment|Informal sector]] to people with disabilities to start up or expand small businesses (primarily in breach of livestock and agriculture), which will be run by themselves or their families.{{cite web|title=Organizacija amputiraca "Udas" RS obezbijedila ekonomsku podršku članovima |url=http://dobojski.info/drustvo-i-politika/item/10881-doboj-organizacija-amputiraca-udas-rs-obezbijedila-ekonomsku-podrsku-clanovim|publisher=Dobojski info|accessdate=23 November 2015}} Beside that, UDAS organised various educational and business seminars, workshops, and consulting. {{cite web|title=Become an Active Job Seeker|url=http://www.ipm-lsi.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=108%3Abudite-aktivan-trazilac-posla&lang=en|publisher=Landmine Survivors Initiatives|accessdate=22 December 2009}} === Legislation and public advocacy=== When it comes to various sectors of public policy, disability is an often misunderstood and stigmatized condition.For that reason, UDAS's leadership takes particular interest in implementation of advocacy, social policies and legislation for persons with disabilities. {{cite web|title=Javne konsultacije analize uskladjenosti zakonodavstva BiH sa UN konvenciom o pravima Osoba sa invaliditetom|url=http://ukljuci.in/bs/oprojektu-3/880-odrzane-druge-javne-konsultacije-analize-uskladenosti-bih-zakonodavstva-sa-un-konvencijom-o-pravima-osoba-sa-invaliditetom-u-oblasti-zaposljavanja.php|publisher=In.projekt|accessdate=18 Jun 2014}}{{cite web|title=Protest UDAS zbog kvaliteta ortopedskih pomagala |url=http://lat.rtrs.tv/vijesti/vijest.php?id=176855|publisher=RTRS|accessdate=19 December 2015}}{{cite web|title=Postuj moje parking mjesto|url=http://www.capital.ba/mercator-i-udas-u-akciji-%E2%80%9Epostuj-moje-mjesto-za-parking/|publisher=18 September 2012}} As a disability right organisation, UDAS in co-operation with Ministries and Services worked on drafting, improvement, practical implementation and adjustment of existing laws and regulations with the [[Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities]].{{cite web|title=Government of Republic of Srpska held 37th Session|url=http://www.vladars.net/eng/vlada/ic/ns/Pages/Government_of_Republic_of_Srpska_held_37th_Session.aspx|publisher=Government Republika Srpska|accessdate=11 December 2014}}{{cite web|title=Odrzan sastanak sa Organizacijom amputiraca RS|url=https://www.zdravstvo-srpske.org/vijesti/odrzan-sastanak-sa-organizacijom-amputiraca-rs.html|publisher=Health Insurance Fund of Republika Srpska|accessdate=18 November 2015}} Outcome of combine actions was on the creation of the Soldiers’ Rights Act, Pension and Disability Insurance Act and Social Protection Act.UDAS as well, mounted activities to train individuals with disabilities about their new rights. UDAS offers to persons with disability a legal support in terms of legal counseling, references and writing acts to relevant institutions.{{cite web|title=Training on "Writing proposals and preparation of local action plans in the field of disability" held in Bijeljina|url=http://ukljuci.in/en/about-project-2/724-training-on-writing-proposals-and-preparation-of-local-action-plans-in-the-field-of-disability-held-in-bijeljina.php|publisher=Ukljuci.In|accessdate=31 March 2014}}{{cite web|title=Report on cooperation between governments and civil society organizations|url=http://www.clusterconvention.org/files/2012/04/Report-on-cooperation-between-governments-and-civil-society-organizations-in-providing-support-to-the-victims.pdf|publisher=ClusterConvention|accessdate=4 April 2012}} === Culture === Through cultural activities, primarily through disability arts UDAS want to create a network of local and regional artists to highlight the barriers faced by persons with disabilities and promote the creative potential of artists on the local, national and regional level. UDAS organizes various cultural and creative projects and activities for persons with and without disabilities, such as: drawing school and painting for children,workshop in creative writing, graphic workshops, [[Art colony|art colonies]], individual and collective exhibitions of art works, where priority is given to persons with disabilities. All activity have a clear psycho therapeutic aspect. Main cultural activity is doing art and handcraft. {{cite web|title=Exhibition in UDAS marking International day of landmine awareness|url=http://ukljuci.in/en/news-2/22-english/551-exhibition-in-udas-marking-international-day-of-landmine-awareness|publisher=Ukljuci.in|accessdate=3 April 2014}} {{cite web|title=2008 Balkana Regional Art Colony: “Art Beyond Borders and Barriers”|url=http://www.advocacynet.org/2008_balkana_regional_art_colony_art_bey/|publisher=The Advocacy Project|accessdate=16 February 2008}}{{cite web|title=Balkana 2009: Art Beyond Borders and Barriers|url=https://alchemedia.wordpress.com/2010/01/15/balkana-2009-art-beyond-borders-and-barriers/|publisher=alchemedia|accessdate=January 15, 2010}} The organization has art gallery ‘Udas', that is unique gallery in the Southeast Europe because it provides an opportunity for young students of the Academy of Fine Arts, aspiring artists and artists with and without disabilities to showcase their artwork, free of charge. Beside gallery, UDAS owns graphic workshop. Art Gallery 'Udas' is only place in Bosnia and Herzegovina where persons with disability have opportunity showcase their art work. Within the gallerie UDAS shows documentaries and movies that are associated directly or indirectly with the present time and situation in society, free of charge. Projections is led by dramaturge, who after the presentation with participants and discuss and analyze the theme the movie.{{cite web|title=Javni konkurs galerije Udas banja luka za 2016 godinu|url=http://www.alu.unsa.ba/content/javni-konkurs-galerije-udas-banja-luka-za-2016-godinu|publisher=ALU Sarajevo|accessdate=1 December 2015}} === Sport === Since a healthful lifestyles is one of most important segments of rehabilitation, the UDAS encourages and supports persons with disabilities (primary amputees) to participation in sport activities, to develop confidence, independence and general health.{{cite web|title=15th International Sitting Volleyball Tournament "Princess Diana Memorial" and The Exhibition of Artworks created at The Regional Art Colony " Arts Beyond Barriers and Boundaries"|url=http://www.bhmac.org/en/stream.daenet?sta=3&pid=647&kat=19|publisher=BHMAC|accessdate=16 October 2012}} In keeping with that UDAS financially supports The Shooting Club of amputees ‘Borac’ Banja Luka through projects and individuals through one-off aid, so amputees could participate in [[disabled sports]]. Beside that UDAS regularly organizes sections in chess,badminton and table tennis. All sports sections are led by persons who are trained to work with disabled people.{{cite web|title=Kolektivna izložba Škole crtanja i slikanja|url=http://www.ukljuci.in/bs/vijesti-3/21-lokalni/2855-kolektivna-izlozba-skole-crtanja-i-slikanja.php|publisher=Ukljuci.in|accessdate=20 Jul 2016}}{{cite web|title=Likovna radionica u Galeriji UDAS|url=http://www.ukljuci.in/bs/vijesti-3/21-lokalni/2838-likovna-radionica-u-galeriji-udas.php|publisher=Ukljuci.in|accessdate=12 July 2016}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.udas.rs.ba/ }} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Bosnia and Herzegovina]] [[Category:Amputee organizations]] [[Category:Non-profit organisations based in Europe]] [[Category:Disability rights organizations]] [[Category:Disability organizations based in Bosnia and Herzegovina]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Organization of Amputees UDAS Republike Srpske}}

The '''Three-Year Plan of Reconstructing the Economy''' ({{lang-pl|Trzyletni Plan Odbudowy Gospodarki}}) was a [[central planning|centralized]] [[Soviet plan|plan]] created by the [[Polish communist]] government to rebuild [[History of Poland (1945–1989)#Wartime devastation|Poland after the devastation of the Second World War]]. The plan was carried out between 1947 to 1949. It succeeded in its primary aim of largely rebuilding Poland from the devastation of the war, as well as in increasing output of Polish industry and agriculture.
==Development and goals== Poland suffered [[World War II casualties|heavy losses during World War II]]. In addition to significant population losses,<ref name="state.gov">US Department of State, Bureau of European and Eurasian Affairs. [https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/2875.htm Background Note: Poland] (March 2007). Retrieved on 2007-04-07</ref> it suffered catastrophic damage to its [[infrastructure]] during the war; the losses in national resources and [[infrastructure]] amounted to over 30% percent of pre-war potential.<ref name="Piotrowski-21">{{cite book | author =Piotrowski, Tadeusz | title = Poland's Holocaust: Ethnic Strife, Collaboration with Occupying Forces and Genocide... | year =1997 |pages =21 | publisher =McFarland & Company | isbn =0-7864-0371-3| url =https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0786403713&id=A4FlatJCro4C&pg=PA295&lpg=PA295&dq=1939+Soviet+citizenship+Poland&sig=qETeuFX3hbmM0VPSO13o0LmjgEc#PPA21,M1 | authorlink = Tadeusz Piotrowski (sociologist) }}</ref> Rebuilding of the economy was also made more difficult by the major [[territorial changes of Poland after World War II]].<ref name="IPN-MM">{{cite web | url= http://www.ipn.gov.pl/biuletyn/13/biuletyn02_2.html | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20050321165047/http://www.ipn.gov.pl/biuletyn/13/biuletyn02_2.html | title= MIĘDZY MODERNIZACJĄ A MARNOTRAWSTWEM | archivedate= 2005-03-21 | publisher= [[Institute of National Remembrance]] | language= Polish }} See also [http://www.niniwa2.cba.pl/komunizm_gospodarka_prl_ipn.htm other copy online] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070426011453/http://www.niniwa2.cba.pl/komunizm_gospodarka_prl_ipn.htm |date=2007-04-26 }}</ref>
The Three-Year Plan was developed and monitored by the [[Central Planning Office]] (''Centralny Urząd Planowania''), a body of the government tasked with creation of [[economic policy]], and in the early years dominated by a more liberal [[Polish Socialist Party]] (PPS) faction.<ref name="IPN-MM"/> Among the economists involved in its development was the then CUP director, [[Czesław Bobrowski]].<ref name="IPN-MM"/> CUP centralized planning for the entire Polish economy was previously broken into separate bodies working on planning for separate branches.
The plan, significantly influenced by the PPS,<ref name="IPN-MM"/> was designed to create a balance between the [[private sector]], the [[public sector]] and the [[cooperatives]].<ref name="IPN-MM"/> Instead of [[ideology]], commonly stressed by later communist plans, it concentrated on the realistic problems and ways to address them.<ref name="IPN-MM"/>
On 21 September 1946 the [[State National Council]] (KRN), a [[Polish communist]]-dominated unelected Polish parliament accepted the plan for the [[Polish economy]] up to 1949. On 2 July 1947 the [[Polish legislative election, 1947|newly elected]] [[Sejm]] declared that: "The primary goal of the national economy in the years 1947-1949 is to raise the [[living conditions]] of working [[social class|classes]] to above the pre-war levels."
The plan as described by the above bodies was designed to develop industry and service sectors, foreign trade and ensure the supply of basic consumer items. The plan specified the size of industrial and agricultural production to be achieved in the following years. In 1949 both the industrial and agricultural productions were to be above the pre-war levels. The industrial output was also to be higher than agricultural output. The plan did not involve creation of new industrial centers, only the rebuilding of the old ones (unless they were over 50% destroyed<ref name="IPN-MM"/>).
==Results and assessment== Due to the dedication of substantial resources to industrial rebuilding, and the successful adoption of the [[Stakhanovite movement]] (the [[communist propaganda]] of that time created a new "hero of the working class", [[Wincenty Pstrowski]]), where workers were encouraged to work above their quota, the expected increase in industrial output was reached ahead of schedule.<ref name="IPN-MM"/> However, the agricultural output did not increase as much as predicted,<ref name="IPN-MM"/> partially due to bad weather in 1947, partially due to inefficiencies involved in [[collectivization]] of farming and finally, partially due to side-effects of the [[battle for trade]], which damaged traditional [[supply chain]]s. In 1948 industrial production was 30% higher compared to 1939, but agricultural production was 30% lower (compared to the 1934-38 period).<ref name="IPN-MM"/>
The battle for trade, pushed for by [[Stalinist]] hardliners like [[Hilary Minc]], suggested that both the cooperative and private sectors should be eliminated and the public sector should be dominant,<ref name="IPN-MM"/><ref name="PWNEnc"/> assumptions contrary to the foundations of the three-year plan which stated that all three sectors are equal.<ref name="IPN-MM"/> The battle for trade also resulted in a decrease of the [[Handicraft|craftmanship]] sector.<ref name="PWNEnc">{{pl icon}} [http://encyklopedia.pwn.pl/haslo.php?id=4575032 Polska. Gospodarka. Przemysł.]. [[Internetowa encyklopedia PWN|Encyklopedia PWN]]</ref>
Already in 1949 the stress was moved from [[consumer goods]] to [[producer goods]], and [[light industry]] development was slowed. The next plan in the Polish communist economy was the [[Six-Year Plan]] (1950–1956), much more critically assessed by modern historians and economists, as by 1950 the CUP and Polish government were dominated by Stalinist hardliners, and PPS economists responsible for creation of the Three-Year Plan were no longer influencing government policy.<ref name="IPN-MM"/><ref name="PWNEnc"/> The Six-Year Plan, designed to bring the [[economy of Poland]] in line with the [[Soviet economy]], concentrated on [[heavy industry|heavy industrialization]], with projects such as [[Nowa Huta]].<ref name="IPN-MM"/>
Rebuilding of the Polish economy was also slowed in 1947, as Soviet influence caused the Polish government to reject the American-sponsored [[Marshall Plan]], designed to aid European economies in post-war rebuilding.<ref name="IPN-MM"/><ref name="Marshall">[[Martin A. Schain|Schain, Martin A.]] ''The Marshall Plan: fifty years after'', Palgrave, 2001, {{ISBN|0-312-22962-3}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=ybAQmmyrLN8C&vid=ISBN0312229623&dq=Poland+Marshall+1947&pg=PA9&lpg=PA9&sig=gUq-CmKAWOBGABGPxCh9QKFqySY&q=Poland#PPA133,M1 Google Print, p.132]</ref>
With the simultaneous rebuilding of the cities, substantial migration from rural areas to urban centers occurred, increasing [[urbanization]]. [[Warsaw]] and other ruined cities were cleared of rubble and rebuilt with great speed during those years.<ref name="poloniatodayhistory">[https://web.archive.org/web/20080117214309/http://www.poloniatoday.com/history13.htm A brief history of Poland. Chapter 13: "The Post-War Years, 1945-1990."] Polonia Today Online. Retrieved on 28 March 2007.</ref> In 1939, 60% of Poles worked in agriculture and 13% in industry; in 1949, the figures were 47% and 21%, respectively.
The three-year plan is widely considered a success and the only efficient economic plan in the history of [[People's Republic of Poland]].<ref name="IPN-MM"/> It succeeded in its primary aim: mostly rebuilding Poland from the devastation of the war, as well as in increasing output of Polish industry and agriculture.<ref name="IPN-MM"/>
==See also== *[[Five-Year Plan (USSR)#Fourth and Fifth Plans.2C 1946–1950 and 1951–1955|The Fourth and Fifth Plans of USSR]] which were aimed at rebuilding USSR after World War II *[[Eastern Bloc economies]]
==Notes== <!--See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes for an explanation of how to generate footnotes using the <ref(erences/)> tags--> {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *Stanley J. Zyzniewski, ''The Soviet Economic Impact on Poland'', American Slavic and East European Review, Vol. 18, No. 2 (Apr., 1959), pp. 205–225, [https://www.jstor.org/stable/3001363 JSTOR] *Werner Stark, ''The Political Element in the Development of Economic Theory:'', Routledge, 1998, {{ISBN|0-415-17535-6}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Wj8tFpWhxIMC&pg=PA57&lpg=PA57&dq=%22three+year+plan%22+poland+1947&source=web&ots=Ha3ZLbl68K&sig=vy1z4uIRf05Muf8u44XYJaMPy8g#PPA71,M1 Google Print, p.60-]

In the United Kingdom''', Trading Standards''' are the local authority departments, formerly known as ''[[Weights and Measures Acts of the United Kingdom|Weights and Measures]]'', that enforce consumer protection legislation.<ref name="WMBC">{{cite web|title=Trading standards|url=https://go.walsall.gov.uk/Business/Trading_standards|website=go.walsall.gov.uk|publisher=Walsall MBC|accessdate=3 April 2018}}</ref>
Sometimes, the Trading Standards enforcement functions of a local authority are performed by part of a larger department which enforces a wide range of other legislation: environmental health, health and safety, licensing and so on. These departments investigate commercial organisations that trade outside the law or in unethical ways. They attempt to remedy breaches by advice or by formal enforcement action.
==History== They were originally labelled as Weights and Measures Departments because their primary function was to maintain the integrity of commercial weighing and measuring by routine testing of equipment and goods. Other legislation was allocated to them as time went on.
==Function== They now deal with more diverse issues under a wide variety of Acts, Orders and Codes of Practice, as set out by central government, the [[Food Standards Agency]]. Such legislation includes the [[Consumer Protection from Unfair Trading Regulations 2008]], the [[Consumer Protection Act 1987]], the [[Consumer Credit Act 1974]], the [[Food Safety Act 1990]], the Price Marking Order 2004 and the [[Consumer Rights Act 2015]]. Recent priorities include prevention of sales of counterfeit goods, sales of tobacco and alcohol to under-age buyers, and action to prevent exploitation of vulnerable consumers by scams and doorstep crime. In 2017, the Trading Standards of [[Somerset]], [[Devon]] and [[Torbay]] donated 5000 items of counterfeit clothes to the charity Planet Zero after the clothes were seized and rebranded.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.devonlive.com/thousands-of-fake-designer-clothes-handed-to-charity/story-30416001-detail/story.html|title=Thousands of fake designer clothes handed to charity|date=2017-06-29|work=Devon Live|access-date=2017-06-30|language=en}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Environmental health]] * [[Chartered Trading Standards Institute]]

1944 as an organization | merger = | split = | predecessor = | merged = | successor = [[Liberal-Progressive]]s,
[[Co-operative Commonwealth Federation of Ontario|Ontario CCF]] | position = | national = | student_wing = | youth_wing = | membership = | membership_year = | colours = [[Green]] | colors = | blank1_title = Fiscal policy | blank1 = | blank2_title = Social policy | blank2 = | seats1_title = Seats in the House of Commons | seats1 = | seats2_title = Seats in the Senate | seats2 = | seats3_title = Seats in [[Legislative Assembly of Ontario|Legislature]] | seats3 = | state = Ontario | parties_dab1 = List of political parties in Ontario | elections_dab1 = List of Ontario general elections | footnotes = }} The '''United Farmers of Ontario''' (UFO) was an [[Agrarianism|agrarian]]{{cite book|editor1=Tony Fitzpatrick|editor2=Huck-ju Kwon|editor3=Nick Manning|editor4=James Midgley|editor5=Gillian Pascall|title=International Encyclopedia of Social Policy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pWcoMn8nvXcC&pg=PA16|year=2006|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-61004-2|pages=15–17}} and [[Populism|populist]]{{cite book|author=Christopher Moore|title=The Court of Appeal for Ontario: Defining the Right of Appeal in Canada, 1792-2013|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-eM7BQAAQBAJ&pg=PA80|year=2014|publisher=University of Toronto Press, Scholarly Publishing Division|isbn=978-1-4426-2248-7|page=80}} provincial [[political party]] in [[Ontario]], Canada. It was the Ontario provincial branch of the [[United Farmers (disambiguation)|United Farmers]] movement of the early part of the 20th century. ==History== ===Foundation and rise (1914-1919)=== [[File:Ernest Drury.jpg|left|thumb|Ernest C. Drury, UFO premier and leader]] The UFO was founded in 1914 by the union of various farmers' organizations that had been created over the previous fifteen years.Macpherson, Ian, [http://thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=A1ARTA0008229 "United Farmers of Ontario"], ''The Canadian Encyclopedia'' [[James J. Morrison]] was the leading figure in the party, serving as its [[general secretary]] and secretary of the United Farmers Co-operative Company Ltd. (the purchasing co-operative the UFO operated on behalf of its members). The organization grew rapidly and by 1917 it had 350 local clubs and 12,000 members.http://www.nfu.ca/ont-1.pdf The UFO had a comprehensive farmer's platform that called for the nationalization of railways, [[progressive tax]]ation, and legislation that would facilitate the operation of [[co-operative]]s. In 1917, supporters of the UFO formed the Farmers' Publishing Company and purchased ''The Weekly Sun'' renaming it ''[[The Farmer's Sun]]'' to act as the organ of the UFO. The UFO entered politics by contesting and winning a [[by-election]] in [[Manitoulin (electoral district)|Manitoulin]] in 1918, in which [[Beniah Bowman]] was elected as the party's first [[Member of the Legislative Assembly]] (MLA). In the [[Ontario general election, 1919|1919 provincial election]], with over 50,000 members, the party sought to hold the [[balance of power (parliament)|balance of power]] so it could introduce legislation friendly to farmers. It co-operated with the [[Labour Party of Canada|Independent Labour Party]] with the two organizations not running candidates against each other - the UFO contested rural ridings and the ILP stood candidates in urban areas. In total there were 64 UFO candidates, 20 ILP candidates and 10 Farmer-Labour candidates in the [[Ontario general election, 1919|1919 provincial election]]. The UFO platform called for the abolition of political [[patronage]], better educational opportunities in rural areas, cheap electric power, conservation of forests, [[proportional representation]] and [[direct democracy|"direct legislation"]]. The UFO also favoured [[prohibition]] and budgetary restraint, two platform planks that were at odds with the views of urban Labour supporters. To the shock of everyone, including itself, it won 45 seats and formed a [[coalition government]] with the support of Labour MLAs in the [[Legislative Assembly of Ontario]] despite having no leader. As the United Farmers began as a [[Single-issue politics|single-issue party]], Morrison opposed forming a government, believing that the party should concern itself solely with [[agricultural]] issues and that it would not be able to represent the entire province. Furthermore, he viewed the [[Labour Party of Canada|Independent Labour Party]] as inimical to farmers' interests and opposed a coalition with them to form a [[majority government]]. Morrison was offered the position of UFO caucus leader and [[Premier of Ontario]] following the election but declined as did Sir [[Adam Beck]]; the position instead went [[Ernest C. Drury]]. ===Forming the government (1919-1923)=== Despite Morrison's objections, the UFO joined with 10 Independent Labour Party MLAs (an 11th ILP MLA, [[Morrison MacBride]], broke with his colleagues and sat in Opposition) and one Independent to form a [[coalition government]], with Drury as [[List of Ontario premiers|Premier]] and two of the ILP MLAs in the cabinet.[http://www.westernnewdemocrats.ca/?page_id=9 Labour and Farmers in Ontario 1919 - 1932], ''History of the NDP'', accessed February 13, 2008 Morrison remained outside of the legislature and government as the general secretary of the UFO. Morrison opposed a number of the coalition's initiatives, perceiving the UFO's actions as a broad-based Progressive government rather than a "class-based" United Farmer government and believed that the party should not be in government but should hold the [[balance of power (parliament)|balance of power]] in order to force the government of the day to pass pro-farmer legislation. Drury's Farmer-Labour government created the first Department of Welfare for the province and brought in allowances for widows and children, a [[minimum wage]] for women and standardized adoption procedures."Free-trader, writer and farmer, former Premier E.C. Drury dies" Globe and Mail, February 19, 1968 His government also expanded [[Hydro-Electric Power Commission of Ontario|Ontario Hydro]] and promoted rural electification, created the [[Province of Ontario Savings Office]] - a provincially owned bank that was designed to lend money to farmers at a lower rate - began the first major reforestation program in North America, and began construction of the modern highway system. The government was also a strict enforcer of [[Temperance movement|temperance]] measures. Drury also arranged for a grant for unknown researchers [[Frederick Banting]] and [[Charles Herbert Best|Charles Best]] who later discovered [[insulin]]. The UFO grew quickly to 1,500 clubs and 60,000 members by 1920. The government under Drury tried to be a "people's government" rather than a "class government" and argued for a "broadening out" of the party to include labour and others, but in so doing, alienated the base of the government's support, particularly farmers. The UFO government clashed with the UFO organization (led by James J. Morrison) which eventually withdrew its support from the government. The party's base of farmer supporters began to turn away from the party, causing the Drury government to lose the [[Ontario general election, 1923|election of 1923]]. Seventeen United Farmer and four Labour members returned to the Legislature, compared to 75 [[Ontario Progressive Conservative Party|Conservatives]]. Drury lost his own seat. ===Decline (1923-1929)=== [[File:Harry Nixon.jpg|left|thumb|[[Harry Nixon]], the last leader of the Progressives.]] Though the United Farmers of Ontario remained the second largest party in the legislature, they were denied [[Official Opposition]] status by [[Conservative Party of Ontario|Conservative]] premier [[Howard Ferguson]]. The position was instead given to the [[Liberal Party of Ontario|Liberals]] with [[W.E.N. Sinclair]] as [[Leader of the Opposition (Ontario)|Leader of the Opposition]], despite the party having three fewer seats than the UFO. Morrison had announced that the UFO would be withdrawing from politics, which Ferguson had used as justification for the move. [[Manning Doherty]], interim leader of the UFO caucus, could do nothing aside from win a ruling from the Speaker that, as leader of a caucus of more than 15 MLAs, he was entitled to an extra salary.Oliver, Peter ''G. Howard Ferguson: Ontario Tory'', Toronto and Buffalo: University of Toronto Press, 1977, p. 158 Eighteen months following the general election, [[William Raney]] was elected unanimously by his caucus as leader of what was now referred to as the "Progressive" bloc of MLAs which had begun as Farmer and Labour MLAs. [[Leslie Oke]] and [[Beniah Bowman]] refused to accept the leadership of Raney, a non-farmer, and also disagreed with the creation of a "Progressive Party" which would include non-farmers - with the support of ''The Farmer's Sun'', they insisted on continuing to sit as UFO members rather than with the Progressive group.{{cite news|title=PROGRESSIVE GROUP CHOOSES MR. RANEY AS HOUSE LEADER|work=The Globe|date=21 January 1925}}{{cite news|title=PROGRESSIVE GROUP WILL LOSE SUPPORT OF FARMER MEMBER: Leslie W. Oke, East Lambton, Not in Accord With Baney Leadership CITY MAN NOT ACCEPTABLE|work=The Globe|date=22 January 1925}}{{cite news|title=BLESSING BESTOWED BY FARMERS' PAPER UPON L. W. OKE, M.P.P.: The Sun Approves His Recent Break With Progressive Group "ONLY POSSIBLE COURSE"|work=The Globe|date=30 January 1925}} Bowman resigned from the legislature in 1926 in order to enter federal politics. The issue which dominated Ontario politics in the mid 1920s was the [[Howard Ferguson|Ferguson]] government's proposal to repeal the ''[[Ontario Temperance Act]]'' and replace prohibition with government control of liquor. The Liberals, were split on the issue - most of their MLAs were "dry" but some were "wets" who were opposed to prohibition. The Progressives under Raney, however, were adamantly in favour of prohibition and opposed to Ferguson's proposals. This led to an estrangement with Labour MLA [[Karl Homuth]] who supported Ferguson's proposals and would eventually join the Conservatives. The [[Ontario general election, 1926|1926 provincial election]] reduced the farmer-labour contingent to thirteen Progressive MLAs and one Labour MLA (Homuth - who had broken with the Progressives and supported the government) while two new UFO MLAs, [[Thomas Farquhar]] and [[Farquhar Oliver]] joined Oke's faction. Several weeks after the election the UFO convention voted to cease running its own candidates though a handful of local UFO clubs continued to nominate candidates for some years. ===End of the movement (1927-1940)=== [[File:Farquhar Oliver.JPG|thumb|Farquhar Oliver, last UFO MLA in the provincial legislature.]] Raney resigned from the legislature the next year in order to accept an appointment to the [[Supreme Court of Ontario]] and 72-year-old [[John Giles Lethbridge]] was chosen as the new leader of the Progressives. In the [[Ontario general election, 1929|1929 election]], only five Progressives, one Labour and one UFO MLA won re-election. Lethbridge, like Raney in the previous election, campaigned largely on the issue of [[prohibition]]. After Lethbridge lost his seat in the 1929 election [[Harry Nixon]], who had served as [[Provincial Secretary]] in Drury's government, became the leader of the remaining Progressives. In the early 1930s, Nixon and the Progressives agreed to an alliance with former UFO activist [[Mitchell Hepburn]] who, in 1930, became leader of the Liberal Party. A group of four [[Liberal-Progressive]] MLAs, led by Nixon, were elected in the [[Ontario general election, 1934|1934 election]], who joined Hepburn to form a government and were eventually absorbed into the Liberal Party. ''(see [[Liberal-Progressive#Ontario|Liberal-Progressives (Ontario)]] for more information)'' In 1932, leading UFO member [[Agnes Macphail]] (originally elected to the [[Progressive Party of Canada|Progressive Party]]) encouraged the UFO to affiliate with [[Co-operative Commonwealth Federation]] (CCF) when it was formed. It did so, and MacPhail became the first Chairman of the [[Ontario CCF]] in 1932, but the UFO disaffiliated from the CCF in 1934 due to allegations of [[Communism|communist]] influence in the party.{{cite news|title=C.C.F. Ontario Provincial Council Suspended: U.F.O. Withdraws And Will Stay Out; Philpott Resigns Agnes Macphail Retires Automatically as Her Repre sentative Capacity in Organization Ceases-- Woodsworth Calls for Reorganization Which Will Rid Federation of Communist Influence-- Statement Issued by Farmers' Secretary POLITICAL LABOR MOVEMENT NOW PLANNED WITHIN C.C.F.|work=The Globe|date=12 March 1934}} The UFO nominated candidates, incumbent MLA Farquhar Oliver and former MLA Leslie Oke, accordingly ran as UFO candidates in the [[Ontario general election, 1934|1934 provincial election]] rather than as CCFers. The UFO, like United Farmers groups in the provinces of western Canada, decided to withdraw entirely from electoral politics though Oliver and Macphail continued to run under the UFO banner until 1940. Many United Farmers joined the CCF as individuals. The UFO's newspaper, ''The Farmer's Sun'', was sold to [[Graham Spry]] and [[Alan Plaunt]] and became an organ for the [[League for Social Reconstruction]] and the Ontario CCF. In the [[Canadian federal election, 1935|1935 federal election]], the UFO's provincial executive voted to endorse the new [[Reconstruction Party of Canada]] formed by [[H.H. Stevens]], however many local UFO groups backed the [[Co-operative Commonwealth Federation]]"Liberals busy, CCF active, other factions hold fire", ''Toronto Daily Star'', July 19, 1935 and UFO MP Agnes MacPhail continued to work with the CCF on an informal basis. Other UFOers backed the Liberals. The Reconstruction Party won 11% of the vote in Ontario in the 1935 federal election, more than the CCF, but failed to win a seat in the province and only won one seat nationally. In 1936, the UFO, the United Farmers’ Co-operative Ltd., and various growers and other agricultural organizations formed the Ontario Chamber of Agriculture which, in 1940, became the [[Ontario Federation of Agriculture]] (OFA), a non-partisan lobbying and marketing organization for farmers. In 1943, the UFO ceased to exist as a formal organization and its remnants were absorbed by the OFA.{{Cite web |url=http://www.ofa.on.ca/uploads/userfiles/files/a%20brief%20history.pdf |title=Archived copy |access-date=2014-12-23 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141223081340/http://www.ofa.on.ca/uploads/userfiles/files/a%20brief%20history.pdf |archive-date=2014-12-23 |dead-url=yes |df= }} In 1948 the United Farmers' Co-operative became the [[United Co-operatives of Ontario]] and remains one of the largest farmer-owned [[co-operative]]s in Canada. In 1940, Oliver, the last remaining UFO member of the Legislature and a supporter of the Hepburn government since 1934, joined the Hepburn cabinet and became a Liberal. MacPhail lost her seat as the last United Farmers MP in the House of Commons in the [[Canadian federal election, 1940|1940 election]]. She turned to provincial politics and won election to the Ontario Legislature as a candidate of the CCF in the [[Ontario general election, 1943|1943 provincial election]] while Oliver became Liberal Party leader in 1945. ==United Farmers Co-operative Company Grocers== Around 1919, the UFO hired [[Theodore Loblaw]] to help launch a chain of cooperative grocery stores, but the attempt failed and Loblaw left to start [[Loblaw Companies|his own grocery chain]]. ==UFO/Progressive leaders== #[[E.C. <!-- Image with unknown copyright status removed: [[File:Iwimi.jpg|300px|thumb|Projected water scarcity in 2025.{{Deletable image-caption|date=May 2012}}]] --> '''Water exports''' involve [[export]]ing [[Fresh water|freshwater]] from one country to another. Large increases in human [[Population growth|population]] and [[economic growth]] throughout the world during the twentieth century placed a huge stress on the world’s freshwater resources. Combined with [[global warming|climate change]], they will place an even greater demand on water resources in this century. Water shortages have become an international concern, and freshwater has been described as “blue gold”<ref name=Barlow>Barlow, Maude, and Clarke, Tony, 2003, ''Blue Gold: The Battle Against Corporate Theft of the World’s Water'', James & James/Earthscan, {{ISBN|1-84407-024-7}}.</ref> and “the oil of the 21st Century.”<ref name=Lawrence>Lawrence, 1996, cited in Anderson, Terry L., and Landry, Clay J., ''Exporting Water To The World''[http://www.ucowr.siu.edu/updates/pdf/V118_A8.pdf].</ref>
==Water exports from Canada to the US== [[File:North America satellite orthographic.jpg|thumb|250px|right|A satellite image of North America. The Great Lakes are in the east, while the south-west clearly lacks water.]] Canada has 7% of the world’s renewable supply of freshwater.<ref name="Environment Canada">Environment Canada [http://www.ec.gc.ca/eau-water/default.asp?lang=En&n=2DE7B40F-1].</ref> Freshwater export between Canada and the US currently takes place at a small scale, mostly as bottled water exports. The [[bottled water]] industry exports water in containers usually no larger than twenty litres.<ref name="Heinmiller" /> But even that can be controversial - the multinational food giant [[Nestlé|Nestle]] was accused of attempting to “drain” the town of [[Hillsburgh, Ontario]], of its water in 2012 and 2013, during a drought.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2013/06/04/nestle-canada-water-drought_n_3385472.html?|title = Nestle Canada Water Dispute: Company Denies It Wants To Take Water During Times Of Drought|date = June 4, 2013|accessdate = March 23, 2015|website = Huffington Post Canada|publisher = |last = Tencer|first = Daniel}}</ref>
Since 1850 Americans have been diverting much of the water of the [[Chicago River]], which would naturally flow into [[Lake Michigan]], into the [[Mississippi River|Mississippi]] basin over [[Chicago Sanitary and Ship Canal]]. In that case, though, the goal was not taking possession of the water that would otherwise end up in the Great Lakes, but directing Chicago's effluent away from Lake Michigan, Chicago's source of water.
=== Needs === Many states in the US have experienced water shortages in the past few decades, creating a market for freshwater that could be profitable for Canada. In the south-western US, growing populations and lifestyles that consume large amounts of water have caused most of the [[aquifer]]s and rivers in the region to be overused. The water in the [[Oglala Aquifer]], which serves much of the west-central US, was used eight times faster in 2001 than the replenishment rate. Demands for this freshwater are expected to increase as the climate warms.<ref name="Schindler">Schindler, D.W., The cumulative effects of climate warming and other stresses on Canadian freshwaters in the new millennium, in Bendell-Young, Leah and Gallaugher, Patricia, 2001, ''Waters in Peril'', Springer Science, {{ISBN|0-7923-7504-1}}.</ref>
As human populations and industries grow and the climate change takes place, greater pressure will be placed on water-rich countries like Canada to export their water to countries that have a water shortage.<ref name="Schindler" /> In early 2014, [[Gary Doer]], Canada’s ambassador to the United States, said that by 2020 the pressure on water quality and quantity would be immense. He predicted that water debates and disputes between the two countries would make the clash over the [[Keystone XL pipeline]] “look silly” by comparison.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-debate/in-a-water-war-canada-could-get-hosed/article17139638/|title = In a water war, Canada could get hosed|date = February 28, 2014|accessdate = March 23, 2015|website = |publisher = The Globe and Mail|last = Mason|first = Gary}}</ref>
=== Proposals === Numerous proposals about transferring large amounts of freshwater from the [[Great Lakes Basin]] into the US have been made. This would involve [[drainage basin|inter-basin]] transport of water across the international boundary between Canada and the US using a man-made [[reservoir]]. None of these proposals have as yet been implemented, mainly due to environmental and financial obstacles.{{Citation needed|date=August 2007}}
Schemes to export water from Canada to the US on a large scale have been proposed in the past. These schemes include: * The [[Great Recycling and Northern Development Canal|Great Recycling and Northern Development (GRAND) Canal]] scheme to dam [[James Bay]], on the southern end of Hudson Bay, to create a freshwater reservoir and divert the water from the 20 rivers that flow into it to [[Georgian Bay]]. The water would then be flushed through the [[Great Lakes]] into pipelines to the south-western US. * The North American Water and Power Alliance ([[NAWAPA]]) project proposed to divert the [[Yukon River|Yukon]], [[Liard]], and [[Peace River (Canada)|Peace]] rivers into the [[Rocky Mountain Trench]] to create an 800 km long reservoir that would transfer water into the US.<ref name="Schindler" /> * During the 1990s, exporting water by ocean-going tankers was proposed to three Canadian provinces.<ref name="Heinmiller" /> In 1991, [[Sun Belt Water Inc.]] of Santa Barbara, California, in partnership with Snowcap Waters Ltd., of Fanny Bay, British Columbia, was selected by the Goleta Water District, of California, to enter a contract to supply bulk water by marine tanker but the government of British Columbia reversed its water export policy and introduced a prohibition on the issuance of water export licences leading to an arbitration claim against Canada under Chapter 11 of the [[North American Free Trade Agreement]] filed by [[Sun Belt Water Inc.]] in 1999. The arbitration remains unresolved. * In 1999 Nova Group Ltd. obtained a permit from the [[Ontario]] government to export 600 millions litres of water annually from [[Lake Superior]] to Asia. Political controversy in Canada and the US caused the government to cancel the permit.<ref name="Anderson">Anderson, Terry L., and Landry, Clay J., ''Exporting Water To The World''[http://www.ucowr.siu.edu/updates/pdf/V118_A8.pdf].</ref>
=== Concerns === In [[Canada]] there have been concerns about exporting water to the United States since the 1960s, when states in the south-western US experienced their first water shortages and began to seek water sources to augment their overstretched supplies.<ref name="Heinmiller">Heinmiller, B. Timothy, Harmonization Through Emulation: Canadian Federalism and Water Export Policy [http://www.cnfs-rcef.net/education/workshop_pdfs/heinmiller_water.pdf].</ref> Large-scale removal of water from lakes would negatively affect their [[ecosystem]]s, increasing pollution concentrations and harming plant and animal [[community|communities]].<ref name="Schindler" />
=== Legal issues === Water has been classed as a commodity under the [[North American Free Trade Agreement]] (NAFTA) since the 1980s. This has increased tensions in the debate about exporting water. Although none of the NAFTA rules force Canada to begin to export its water in bulk, if Canada voluntarily decides to begin exports it would be very difficult to later halt them.<ref name="Heinmiller" />
In 2002 the Federal government of Canada passed the [[International Boundary Waters Treaty Act]]. This banned the removal of more than 50 million cubic meters of water from a water basin in the Great Lakes in one day. The Boundary Waters Treaty is limited to waters on the Canadian-US border and does not apply to freshwater in other parts of Canada. This means the about 85 percent of Canada’s water is susceptible to export.<ref name="Fischhendler">Fischhendler, Itay, 2003, Can Basin Management Be Successfully Ignored: The Case Of The US-Canada Transboundary Water, SOAS Water Issues Study Group [http://www.soas.ac.uk/waterissues/occasionalpapers/OCC52.pdf].</ref>
=== Alaska === Since Canada has taken a strong position against water exports, some companies have shifted their focus to [[Alaska]].<ref name="Anderson" /> Alaska was the first jurisdiction in the world to permit the commercial export of bulk water, and has a large potential for water exports.<ref name="Barlow" /> One scheme proposes transporting water from Alaska to [[China]] by tanker. This water would be used to assemble [[Wafer fabrication|computer wafers]] by China’s relatively cheap labour force. Computer wafers require extremely pure freshwater. This makes the cost of [[desalination]] of saltwater prohibitively expensive, making schemes like this, that would not be profitable for domestic purposes, profitable for industrial purposes.<ref name="Figueres">Figuères, Caroline M., Tortaiada, Cecilia, and Rockström, Johan, 2003, ''Rethinking Water Management: Innovative Approaches to Contemporary Issues'', James & James/Earthscan, {{ISBN|1-85383-999-X}}, page 57-60.</ref>
==Water exports within States in the United States== On June 13, 2013, the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] unanimously upheld lower court rulings in Tarrant Regional Water District v. Herrmann, holding that [[Oklahoma]] state water laws validly barred state entities from selling water for out-of-state use, via the Red River Compact among Oklahoma, Texas, Arkansas and Louisiana.<ref>{{cite news |title=U.S. Supreme Court Sides with Oklahoma In Dispute with Texas Water District |url=http://www.natlawreview.com/article/us-supreme-court-sides-oklahoma-dispute-texas-water-district |accessdate=29 June 2013 |newspaper=The National Law Review |date=June 28, 2013 |author1=Daniel M. Krainin |author2=Edward M. Grauman |author3=Karen M. Hansen |author4=Madeleine Boyer Kadas |author5=Laura L. LaValle |author6=Bryan J. Moore |agency=Beveridge & Diamond PC}}</ref> ==Water export in Germany== While the [[Rhine–Main–Danube Canal]] was primarily built as a freight link across the European Main Watershed (linking North Sea and Black Sea via inland waterways), it is also used to transport water from the Danube to the less water-rich rivers of [[Franconia]] and adjacent regions. To this end several artificial lakes like the [[Großer Brombachsee]] were created.
==Water exports from Russia to Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan== {{main|Northern river reversal}} Arid but densely populated southern [[Kazakhstan]] and adjacent [[Central Asian]] states occupy somewhat similar position with respect to [[Russia]]'s Siberia as the south-western United States do with respect to Canada. Siberian rivers, as well as rivers of northern European Russia flow "uselessly" into the seas of the Arctic Ocean, while that water could be much more profitably used for irrigated agriculture by Russia's southern neighbors. Not surprisingly, [[Northern river reversal|proposals]] for large-scale transfer of water from the [[Ob River]] in Siberia to the [[Aral Sea]] basin in Kazakhstan and [[Uzbekistan]] have been seriously considered by the [[USSR|Soviet]] federal government already in the 1960-80s, when all republics involved were members of the USSR. While welcomed by many in Central Asian republics, the project received severe criticism from many scientists as well as prominent writers and journalists in Russia, such as [[Valentin Rasputin]] and [[Sergey Pavlovich Zalygin|Sergey Zalygin]], sometimes known collectively as the "Siberian environmental lobby"<ref>Ronnie D. Lipschutz, Ken Conca, "The State and Social Power in Global Environmental Politics". Columbia University Press, 1993. {{ISBN|0-231-08107-3}}. [https://books.google.com/books?id=gZsmfxeQQGEC Book info on Google Books]</ref>
Shelved in 1986 for both economical and environmental reasons,<ref name=weiner>Douglas R. Weiner, "A Little Corner of Freedom: Russian Nature Protection from Stalin to Gorbachev". University of California Press, 1999. {{ISBN|0-520-23213-5}}. [https://books.google.com/books?id=2rRjx4pCEx0C On Google Books] p. 415</ref> the idea of international water transfers has been raised again in the 21st century in the ruling circles of the now independent states. Both the Kazakh President [[Nursultan Nazarbayev]] and the Uzbek President [[Islam Karimov]] expressed interest in such a water transfer scheme. While the Russian federal government so far remains non-committal on the issue, the plan met enthusiastic response from Moscow mayor and Russian presidential hopeful, [[Yuri Luzhkov]].<ref>By Bess A. Brown, [http://www.hri.org/news/balkans/rferl/2002/02-09-30.rferl.html#78 UZBEKISTAN RESURRECTS RIVER-DIVERSION SCHEME: DESPERATION OR INSPIRATION?]</ref> <ref>Rustam Temirov, [http://www.eurasianet.org/departments/environment/articles/eav021903.shtml LOBBYING GROWS IN MOSCOW FOR SIBERIA-UZBEKISTAN WATER SCHEME]. 2/19/2003.</ref> <ref>Sergei Blagov, [http://www.jamestown.org/edm/article.php?article_id=2371408 KAZAKHSTAN, KYRGYZSTAN, UZBEKISTAN, AND TAJIKISTAN SIGN PACT TO PRESERVE ARAL SEA]. September 5, 2006</ref> <ref>[http://iwpr.net/report-news/siberian-river-project-revived Siberian River Project Revived] 08-Sep-06</ref>
==Alternatives to large-scale water exports== In the short run, better allocation of resources and more efficient [[water conservation]] technology may keep demand for water in some countries under control. However, a water crisis may occur in the near future that would make bulk water export a more favourable plan.{{Citation needed|date=August 2007}}
The canals that would have to be constructed to transfer water require huge investment and operation costs. This would make the cost for consumers of the water expensive. In contrast, the technology needed to desalinise seawater has improved dramatically and has an acceptable cost for urban markets. Whether or not pressures for large-scale water exports continues to increase depends mostly on future advances in desalination technology. If the cost of desalination drops enough, it will be cheaper to generate freshwater from saltwater than to import freshwater from another country. The cost of desalination is currently less than US$1 per cubic meter. The [[World Water Commission]] has suggested that desalination will become the favoured method of procuring drinking and industrial-use waters. However, the need for extremely pure water for particular industrial uses would still require freshwater imports.<ref name=Figueres/>
